techs.name: Agriculture
techs.quote: 'The discovery of agriculture was the first big step toward a civilized life.' — Sir Arthur Keith, Evolution and Ethics (1947).

techs.name: Pottery
techs.quote: 'For I remember stopping by the way / To watch a Potter thumping his wet Clay: / And with its all-obliterated Tongue / It murmur’d—‘Gently, Brother, gently, pray!’' — Omar Khayyam, Rubáiyát (tr. Edward FitzGerald).

techs.name: Animal Husbandry
techs.quote: Where no oxen are, the crib is clean; but much increase is by the strength of the ox.” — Proverbs 14:4.

techs.name: Archery
techs.quote: 'The bow too tensely strung is easily broken.' — Publilius Syrus.

techs.name: Mining
techs.quote: 'Surely there is a mine for silver, and a place where gold is refined.' — Book of Job 28:1.

techs.name: Sailing
techs.quote: 'A ship in harbor is safe, but that’s not what ships are built for.' — John A. Shedd.

techs.name: Calendar
techs.quote: 'Every time you tear a leaf off a calendar, you present a new place for new ideas and progress.' — Charles F. Kettering.

techs.name: Writing
techs.quote: 'Writing is the painting of the voice.' — Voltaire.

techs.name: Trapping
techs.quote: 'Build a better mousetrap, and the world will beat a path to your door.' — Ralph Waldo Emerson.

techs.name: The Wheel
techs.quote: 'Everything the Power of the World does is done in a circle.' — Black Elk, Black Elk Speaks, ch. 17.

techs.name: Masonry
techs.quote: 'Therefore, when we build, let us think that we build for ever… and let us think, as we lay stone on stone, that a time is to come when those stones will be held sacred because our hands have touched them.' — John Ruskin, The Seven Lamps of Architecture (1849).

techs.name: Bronze Working
techs.quote: 'Their armor was of bronze, and their houses of bronze, and of bronze were their implements: there was no black iron.' — Hesiod, Works and Days (Ages of Man).

techs.name: Optics
techs.quote: 'Truth is sought for its own sake… Finding the truth is difficult, and the road to it is rough.' — Ibn al-Haytham (Alhazen), from his writings on optics.

techs.name: Philosophy
techs.quote: 'The unexamined life is not worth living.' — Socrates (Plato, Apology 38a).

techs.name: Horseback Riding
techs.quote: 'What a horse does under compulsion he does blindly; his performance is no more beautiful than that of a dancer taught by whip and goad.' — Xenophon, On Horsemanship.

techs.name: Mathematics
techs.quote: 'Pure mathematics is, in its way, the poetry of logical ideas.' — Albert Einstein.

techs.name: Construction
techs.quote: 'Architecture starts when you carefully put two bricks together. There it begins.' — Ludwig Mies van der Rohe.

techs.name: Iron Working
techs.quote: 'As iron sharpens iron, so one person sharpens another.' — Proverbs 27:17.

techs.name: Theology
techs.quote: 'For understanding is the reward of faith. Therefore do not seek to understand in order to believe, but believe that you may understand.' — St. Augustine, Tractates on the Gospel of John 29.6.

techs.name: Civil Service
techs.quote: 'Ask not what your country can do for you—ask what you can do for your country.' — John F. Kennedy, Inaugural Address (Jan 20, 1961).

techs.name: Currency
uniques: Enables conversion of city production to [Gold]
techs.quote: 'They were the first of men, so far as we know, who struck and used coin of gold or silver.' — Herodotus, Histories 1.94.

techs.name: Engineering
techs.quote: 'Scientists discover the world that exists; engineers create the world that never was.' — Theodore von Kármán.

techs.name: Metal Casting
techs.quote: 'I sent for all my pewter platters, porringers, and dishes… This expedient succeeded… while I, now here, now there, gave orders, helped with my own hands.' — Benvenuto Cellini, describing the bronze casting of Perseus.

techs.name: Compass
techs.quote: 'At night they steer by the stars, and in the day-time by the sun. In dark weather they look at the south-pointing needle.' — Zhu Yu, Pingzhou Table Talks (1119).

techs.name: Education
uniques: Enables conversion of city production to [Science]
techs.quote: 'Education, then, beyond all other devices of human origin, is the great equalizer of the conditions of men—the balance-wheel of the social machinery.' — Horace Mann.

techs.name: Chivalry
techs.quote: 'To give mercy unto him that asketh mercy.' — Sir Thomas Malory, Le Morte d’Arthur (Pentecostal Oath).

techs.name: Machinery
techs.quote: 'One machine can do the work of fifty ordinary men. No machine can do the work of one extraordinary man.' — Elbert Hubbard.

techs.name: Physics
techs.quote: 'What I cannot create, I do not understand.' — Richard Feynman (from his Caltech blackboard, 1988).

techs.name: Steel
techs.quote: 'The finest steel has to go through the hottest fire.' — Richard M. Nixon.

techs.name: Astronomy
uniques: Enables [Embarked] units to enter ocean tiles
techs.quote: 'For my part I know nothing with any certainty, but the sight of the stars makes me dream.' — Vincent van Gogh (letter to Theo, 1888).

techs.name: Acoustics
techs.quote: 'If a tree falls in a forest and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound?' — Traditional philosophical question (attested in print by the 1880s).

techs.name: Banking
techs.quote: 'Every banker knows that if he has to prove he is worthy of credit, in fact his credit is gone.' — Walter Bagehot, Lombard Street (1873).

techs.name: Printing Press
techs.quote: 'The printing press is the greatest weapon in the armoury of the modern commander.' —T. E. Lawrence, The Evolution of a Revolt (1920).

techs.name: Gunpowder
techs.quote: 'For sounds like thunder, and coruscations like lightning, may be made in the air… A small quantity of matter, properly prepared, no bigger than a thumb, produces a noise exceeding thunder and a flash brighter than lightning.' — Roger Bacon.

techs.name: Navigation
techs.quote: 'I whose ambition leads me not only farther than any other man has been before me, but as far as I think it possible for man to go.' — Captain James Cook (journal, Jan 30, 1774).

techs.name: Economics
techs.quote: 'The ideas of economists and political philosophers, both when they are right and when they are wrong, are more powerful than is commonly understood. Indeed the world is ruled by little else.' — John Maynard Keynes, The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money, Ch. 24.

techs.name: Chemistry
techs.quote: 'Nothing is lost, nothing is created, everything is transformed.' — Antoine Lavoisier, paraphrasing the law of conservation of mass.

techs.name: Metallurgy
techs.quote: 'Gold is for the mistress, silver for the maid, copper for the craftsman… But iron—cold iron—is master of them all.” — Rudyard Kipling.

techs.name: Archaeology
techs.quote: 'Can you see anything?' — 'Yes, wonderful things.' — Howard Carter, upon first peering into Tutankhamun’s tomb (Nov. 26, 1922).

techs.name: Scientific Theory
techs.quote: 'A theory which is not refutable by any conceivable event is non-scientific. Irrefutability is not a virtue of a theory … but a vice.' — Karl Popper, Conjectures and Refutations.

techs.name: Military Science
techs.quote: 'In war, the morale is to the physical as three to one.' — Napoleon Bonaparte.

techs.name: Fertilizer
techs.quote: 'A manure containing several ingredients acts in this wise: the effect of all of them in the soil accommodates itself to that one among them which, in comparison to the wants of the plant, is present in the smallest quantity.' — Justus von Liebig, Natural Laws of Husbandry (1863).

techs.name: Rifling
techs.quote: 'The rifle is a weapon. Let there be no mistake about that.' — Jeff Cooper, The Art of the Rifle.

techs.name: Biology
techs.quote: 'Life did not take over the globe by combat, but by networking.' — Lynn Margulis, Microcosmos

techs.name: Steam Power
techs.quote: 'I sell here, Sir, what all the world desires to have — Power.' — Matthew Boulton (on the Watt steam engine, 1776).

techs.name: Dynamite
techs.quote: 'My dynamite will sooner lead to peace than a thousand world conventions. As soon as men will find that in one instant, whole armies can be utterly destroyed, they surely will abide by golden peace.' — Alfred Nobel.

techs.name: Electricity
techs.quote: 'Why, sir, there is every probability that you will soon be able to tax it.' — Michael Faraday (to William Gladstone, on electricity).

techs.name: Replaceable Parts
techs.quote: 'In the past the man has been first; in the future the system must be first.' — Frederick Winslow Taylor, The Principles of Scientific Management.

techs.name: Railroads
techs.quote: 'Faster than fairies, faster than witches, / Bridges and houses, hedges and ditches…' — Robert Louis Stevenson, 'From a Railway Carriage' (1885).

techs.name: Refrigeration
techs.quote: 'I found that foods frozen very quickly in the dead of winter kept their freshness as long as they were held at a low temperature.' — Clarence Birdseye.

techs.name: Telegraph
techs.quote: 'We are in great haste to construct a magnetic telegraph from Maine to Texas; but Maine and Texas, it may be, have nothing important to communicate.' — Henry David Thoreau, Walden (1854).

techs.name: Radio
techs.quote: 'Radio affects most intimately, person-to-person, offering a world of unspoken communication between writer-speaker and the listener.' — Marshall McLuhan, Understanding Media (1964).

techs.name: Flight
techs.quote: 'The airplane has unveiled for us the true face of the earth.' — Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, Wind, Sand and Stars.

techs.name: Combustion
techs.quote: 'The production of heat alone is not sufficient to give birth to impelling power; it is necessary that there should also be cold.' — Sadi Carnot, Reflections on the Motive Power of Fire (1824).

techs.name: Pharmaceuticals
techs.quote: 'All things are poison and nothing is without poison; only the dose makes a thing not a poison.' — Paracelsus.

techs.name: Plastics
techs.quote: 'More than a substance, plastic is the very idea of its infinite transformation; as its everyday name indicates, it is ubiquity made visible.' — Roland Barthes, Mythologies ('Plastic').

techs.name: Electronics
techs.quote: 'The future of integrated electronics is the future of electronics itself.' — Gordon E. Moore, 1965.

techs.name: Mass Media
techs.quote: 'Freedom of the press is guaranteed only to those who own one.' — A. J. Liebling.

techs.name: Radar
techs.quote: 'Give them the third best to go on with; the second best comes too late, the best never comes.' — Sir Robert Watson-Watt (on developing radar).

techs.name: Atomic Theory
techs.quote: 'The first principles of the universe are atoms and empty space; everything else is merely thought to exist.' — Diogenes Laertius on Democritus.

techs.name: Ecology
techs.quote: 'When we try to pick out anything by itself, we find it hitched to everything else in the universe.' — John Muir, My First Summer in the Sierra (1911).

techs.name: Computers
techs.quote: 'We can only see a short distance ahead, but we can see plenty there that needs to be done.' — Alan Turing.

techs.name: Rocketry
techs.quote: 'It is difficult to say what is impossible, for the dream of yesterday is the hope of today and the reality of tomorrow.' — Robert H. Goddard.

techs.name: Lasers
techs.quote: 'A laser is a solution looking for a problem.' — Theodore H. Maiman.

techs.name: Nuclear Fission
techs.quote: 'That night, there was very little doubt in my mind that the world was headed for grief.' — Leó Szilárd.

techs.name: Globalization
techs.quote: 'The earth is but one country, and mankind its citizens.' — Bahá’u’lláh.

techs.name: Robotics
techs.quote: 'Let us remember that the automatic machine is the precise economic equivalent of slave labor. Any labor which competes with slave labor must accept the economic consequences of slave labor.' — Norbert Wiener, Cybernetics.

techs.name: Satellites
techs.quote: 'Earth is the cradle of humanity, but one cannot live in a cradle forever.' — Konstantin E. Tsiolkovsky (1911).

techs.name: Stealth
techs.quote: 'The greatest trick the Devil ever pulled was convincing the world he didn’t exist.' — Charles Baudelaire; The Usual Suspects (1995).

techs.name: Advanced Ballistics
techs.quote: 'It has been observed that missiles and projectiles describe a curved path of some sort; however no one has pointed out the fact that this path is a parabola.' — Galileo Galilei, Dialogues Concerning Two New Sciences.

techs.name: Particle Physics
techs.quote: 'Everything not forbidden is compulsory.' — Murray Gell-Mann, describing particle-physics interactions (the “totalitarian principle”).

techs.name: Nuclear Fusion
techs.quote: 'A star is drawing on some vast reservoir of energy… we sometimes dream that man will one day learn to release it and use it for his service. The store is well-nigh inexhaustible, if only it could be tapped.' — Arthur Eddington, The Internal Constitution of the Stars (1926).

techs.name: Nanotechnology
techs.quote: 'There’s plenty of room at the bottom.' — Richard Feynman (1959 lecture on manipulating matter atom-by-atom).

techs.name: Future Tech
techs.quote: 'The future is already here — it’s just not evenly distributed.' — William Gibson.

civilopediaText.text: Who can say what comes next?
